hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: חֲמִשִּׁים כַּחֲמִשִּׁים שֶׁבָּעֲרָכִין. מַאי טַעְמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן? גָּמַר ״נְתִינָה״ ״נְתִינָה״ מֵעֲרָכִין, מָה לְהַלָּן חֲמִשִּׁים – אַף כָּאן חֲמִשִּׁים. וְאֵימָא: כַּפָּחוּת שֶׁבָּעֲרָכִין! ״אֲשֶׁר בֵּרַכְךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ״ כְּתִיב.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: fifty like the fifty of valuations What is the reasoning of Rabbi Shimon? He derived “giving” “giving” from valuations Just as there, fifty, so too here, fifty. But say the smallest of the valuations, it is written: “Of that with which the Lord your God has blessed you”
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: Fifty like fifty of the Arks. What is the reason of Rabbi Shimon? He learned "N'tinah, N'tinah" from the Arks, just as there fifty - so too here fifty. And say: The smallest of the Arks! "Which the Lord your God has blessed you" is written.

hebrew_text: וְנֵילַף ״נְתִינָה״ ״נְתִינָה״ מֵעֶבֶד, מָה לְהַלָּן שְׁלֹשִׁים – אַף כָּאן שְׁלֹשִׁים; חֲדָא, דְּתָפַשְׂתָּה מְרוּבֶּה לֹא תָּפַשְׂתָּה, וְעוֹד, עֶבֶד מֵעֶבֶד הֲוָה לֵיהּ לְמֵילַף! רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן ״מִיכָה״ ״מִיכָה״ גָּמַר.
human_translation: But let derive, “giving” “giving” from slave, just as there thirty, so too here, thirty? One that if you grasped too much, you did not grasp anything; if you grasped a bit, you grasped And furthermore, one should derive of a slave from a slave. Rabbi Shimon derives poverty poverty.
llm_translation: And we learn "N'tinah" "N'tinah" from a slave, just as there it is thirty - so too here it is thirty; one, that if she was captured by a majority, she is not considered captured, and furthermore, a slave from a slave is considered to be a separate entity! Rabbi Shimon concluded "Mikah" "Mikah".

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר, הַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב צֹאן גּוֹרֶן וָיֶקֶב. אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הַאי צֹאן גּוֹרֶן וָיֶקֶב לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: Granted, to Rabbi Meir, this is as it is written “flock,” “threshing floor,” and “winepress,” But according to Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, why do I these “flock,” “threshing floor,” and “winepress,”
llm_translation: In truth, according to Rabbi Meir, that is what is written: "Cattle in the stalls, and the yield of the vineyard." But according to Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, why do I need this cattle in the stalls and the yield of the vineyard?

hebrew_text: הַאי מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְתַנְיָא: יָכוֹל לֹא יְהוּ מַעֲנִיקִין אֶלָּא מִצֹּאן גּוֹרֶן וָיֶקֶב, מִנַּיִן לְרַבּוֹת כׇּל דָּבָר – תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אֲשֶׁר בֵּרַכְךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ״. אִם כֵּן מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר צֹאן גּוֹרֶן וָיֶקֶב? לוֹמַר לָךְ: מָה צֹאן גּוֹרֶן וָיֶקֶב מְיוּחָדִים, שֶׁיֶּשְׁנָן בִּכְלַל בְּרָכָה – אַף כֹּל שֶׁיֶּשְׁנָן בִּכְלַל בְּרָכָה, יָצְאוּ כְּסָפִים, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: יָצְאוּ פְּרָדוֹת.
human_translation: These are necessary for that which is taught might one grants severance gifts only the flock, the threshing floor, and the winepress; from where to include every matter? The verse states: “Of that with which the Lord your God has blessed you” If so, what the verse states “flock,” “threshing floor,” and “winepress”? to tell you just as a flock, a threshing floor, and a winepress are unique in that they are included in blessing, so too all that are included in blessing excludes money, the statement of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: excludes mules,
llm_translation: This is what he seeks to learn according to the teaching: Can one only give Ma'aser from the produce of the threshing floor and winepress? From where do we derive to include everything? The Torah states: "Which the Lord your God has blessed you with." If so, why does the Torah specifically mention the produce of the threshing floor and winepress? To teach you: Just as the produce of the threshing floor and winepress are unique in that they are included in the blessing, so too, everything that is included in the blessing, such as coins, is exempt. These are the words of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: Cattle are exempt.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן? פְּרָדוֹת מַשְׁבְּחָן בְּגוּפַיְיהוּ. וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב? כְּסָפִים עָבֵיד בְּהוּ עִיסְקָא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon, mules, their bodies enhance. And Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, one can conduct business with money
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon? Parados praise in their bodies. And Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov? Silver he made in it business.

hebrew_text: וּצְרִיכָא, דְּאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא צֹאן, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים – אִין, גִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע – לָא, כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא גּוֹרֶן. וְאִי כְּתַב גּוֹרֶן, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: גִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע – אִין, בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים – לָא, כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא צֹאן. יֶקֶב לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: And it is necessary as, if the Merciful One had written “flock,” I would say animals, yes, grows from the ground, no, the Merciful One writes “threshing floor.” And if had written “threshing floor,” I would say grows from the ground, yes, animals, no, the Merciful One writes “flock.” why do I a winepress?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And the necessity is, that if the Merciful One wrote "flock," I would say living creatures - no, cultivated produce - no, the Merciful One wrote "threshing floor." And if He wrote "threshing floor," I would say: cultivated produce - no, living creatures - no, the Merciful One wrote "flock." Why do I need a winepress?

hebrew_text: לְמָר – לְמַעוֹטֵי כְּסָפִים, לְמָר – לְמַעוֹטֵי פְּרָדוֹת.
human_translation: to Master, to exclude money. to Master, to exclude mules.
llm_translation: Master - to lessen silver, master - to lessen livestock.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״אֲשֶׁר בֵּרַכְךָ ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ״, יָכוֹל נִתְבָּרֵךְ בַּיִת בִּגְלָלוֹ – מַעֲנִיקִים לוֹ, לֹא נִתְבָּרֵךְ בַּיִת בִּגְלָלוֹ – אֵין מַעֲנִיקִים לוֹ, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״הַעֲנֵק תַּעֲנִיק״ – מִכׇּל מָקוֹם. אִם כֵּן, מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״אֲשֶׁר בֵּרַכְךָ״ – הַכֹּל לְפִי בְּרָכָה תֵּן לוֹ.
human_translation: The Sages taught of that with which the Lord your God has blessed you” might house is blessed due to him, grants him a severance gift, house is not blessed due to him, does not grant him a severance gift. the verse states: “You shall grant severance [ ha’anek ta’anik ],” in any case. If so, what the verse states: “Of that with which has blessed you”? all gives him in accordance with the blessing
llm_translation: The sages taught: "When the Lord your God blesses you," one might think that one should bless the house because of Him - they provide for him; if one does not bless the house because of Him - they do not provide for him. The verse teaches: "You shall surely give" - from any place. If so, why does the verse say "When the Lord your God blesses you"? Give everything according to the blessing.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה אוֹמֵר: דְּבָרִים כִּכְתָבָן. נִתְבָּרֵךְ בַּיִת בִּגְלָלוֹ – מַעֲנִיקִים לוֹ, לֹא נִתְבָּרֵךְ בַּיִת בִּגְלָלוֹ – אֵין מַעֲנִיקִים לוֹ. אִם כֵּן מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״הַעֲנֵיק תַּעֲנִיק״? דִּבְּרָה תוֹרָה כִלְשׁוֹן בְּנֵי אָדָם.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says: statements as they are written, the house was blessed due to him, grants him a severance gift, the house was not blessed due to him, does not grant him a severance gift If so, what the verse states: “You shall grant severance [ ha’anek ta’anik ],” The Torah spoke in the language of people,
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah says: Words as they were written. If a blessing was said over a house because of it - they give to him, if a blessing was not said over a house because of it - they do not give to him. If so, what is the Talmud to say: "You shall surely give"? The Torah spoke in the language of people.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: עֶבֶד עִבְרִי עוֹבֵד אֶת הַבֵּן, וְאֵינוֹ עוֹבֵד אֶת הַבַּת. אָמָה עִבְרִיָּה אֵינָהּ עוֹבֶדֶת לֹא אֶת הַבֵּן וְלֹא אֶת הַבַּת. הַנִּרְצָע וְהַנִּמְכָּר לְנׇכְרִי אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵד לֹא אֶת הַבֵּן וְלֹא אֶת הַבַּת. אָמַר מָר: עֶבֶד עִבְרִי עוֹבֵד אֶת הַבֵּן, וְאֵינוֹ עוֹבֵד אֶת הַבַּת. מְנָהָנֵי מִילֵּי?
human_translation: The Sages taught: A Hebrew slave serves the son but does not serve the daughter. A Hebrew maidservant serves neither the son nor the daughter, A pierced and sold to a gentile serve neither the son nor the daughter. The Master said A Hebrew slave serves the son but does not serve the daughter. From where is this matter
llm_translation: The rabbis taught: A Hebrew slave serves the son, but does not serve the daughter. A Hebrew maidservant does not serve either the son or the daughter. One who is freed or sold to a non-Jew does not serve either the son or the daughter. Mar said: A Hebrew slave serves the son, but does not serve the daughter. What is the reasoning for these matters?

hebrew_text: דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״וַעֲבָדְךָ שֵׁשׁ שָׁנִים״ – לְךָ וְלֹא לַיּוֹרֵשׁ. אַתָּה אוֹמֵר: לְךָ וְלֹא לַיּוֹרֵשׁ, אוֹ אֵינוֹ אֶלָּא: לְךָ וְלֹא לַבֵּן? כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר: שֵׁשׁ שָׁנִים יַעֲבֹד״, הֲרֵי לַבֵּן אָמוּר, הָא מָה אֲנִי מְקַיֵּים: ״וַעֲבָדְךָ שֵׁשׁ שָׁנִים״ לְךָ – וְלֹא לַיּוֹרֵשׁ.
human_translation: As the Sages taught, “And he shall serve you six years” you and not an heir, you say: You and not an heir, or is it even: You and not a son? When it says: “Six years he shall labor” a son is stated. How do I uphold “And he shall serve you six years”? you but not an heir
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "And your servant shall serve six years" - for you and not for the heir. You may say: for you and not for the heir, or perhaps it means: for you and not for the son? When he says, "Six years he shall serve," it is indeed referring to the son. How then do I fulfill the verse: "And your servant shall serve six years" for you - and not for the heir.

hebrew_text: מָה רָאִיתָ לְרַבּוֹת אֶת הַבֵּן, וּלְהוֹצִיא אֶת הָאָח? מְרַבֶּה אֲנִי אֶת הַבֵּן – שֶׁכֵּן קָם תַּחַת אָבִיו לִיעִדָה וְלִשְׂדֵה אֲחוּזָּה.
human_translation: What did you see to include the son and to exclude the brother I include the son, as he stands in place of his father to designate her. And to an ancestral field
llm_translation: "What did you see to include the son and to exclude the brother? I increase the son - for he stands in place of his father for inheritance and for possession of land."

hebrew_text: אַדְּרַבָּה, מְרַבֶּה אֲנִי אֶת הָאָח שֶׁכֵּן קָם תַּחַת אָחִיו לְיִבּוּם! כְּלוּם יֵשׁ יִבּוּם אֶלָּא בְּמָקוֹם שֶׁאֵין בֵּן? הָא יֵשׁ בֵּן – אֵין יִבּוּם.
human_translation: On the contrary, I include the brother, as he stands in his brother’s place with regard to levirate marriage. is there levirate marriage other in a case when there is no son? there is a son, there is no levirate marriage.
llm_translation: AdRabba, I increase the brother that so stood in place of his brother for levirate marriage! Perhaps there is levirate marriage only in a case where there is no son? But if there is a son - there is no levirate marriage.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא טַעְמָא דְּאִיכָּא הָא פִּירְכָא, הָא לָאו הָכִי אָח עֲדִיף? וְתִיפּוֹק לִי דְּהָכָא תַּרְתֵּי, וְהָכָא חֲדָא!
human_translation: Rather, the reason for there is this refutation without this a brother is preferable But let me derive from here, two and here, one:
llm_translation: Rather, the reason that there is a distinction here is not so? And you should come out to me that here are two, and here is one!

hebrew_text: שְׂדֵה אֲחוּזָּה נָמֵי, מֵהַאי פִּירְכָא הוּא דְּקָא נָפְקָא לֵיהּ לְתַנָּא: כְּלוּם יֵשׁ יִבּוּם אֶלָּא בְּמָקוֹם שֶׁאֵין בֵּן?
human_translation: an ancestral field too, the tanna derives from this refutation. Is there levirate marriage other in a case when there is no son?
llm_translation: Field of ancestral possession, from this inference it emerges to him to the Mishnah: "If there is no levirate marriage except in a place where there is no son?"

hebrew_text: אָמָה הָעִבְרִיָּה אֵינָהּ עוֹבֶדֶת לֹא אֶת הַבֵּן וְלֹא אֶת הַבַּת. מְנָהָנֵי מִילֵּי? אָמַר רַבִּי פְּדָא: דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״וְאַף לַאֲמָתְךָ תַּעֲשֶׂה כֵּן״ – הִקִּישָׁהּ הַכָּתוּב לַנִּרְצָע, מָה נִרְצָע אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵד לֹא אֶת הַבֵּן וְלֹא אֶת הַבַּת – אַף אָמָה הָעִבְרִיָּה אֵינָהּ עוֹבֶדֶת לֹא אֶת הַבֵּן וְלֹא אֶת הַבַּת. וְהַאי ״לַאֲמָתְךָ תַּעֲשֶׂה כֵּן״ לְהָכִי הוּא דַּאֲתָא? הָא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְתַנְיָא: ״וְאַף לַאֲמָתְךָ תַּעֲשֶׂה כֵּן״ – לְהֶעֱנֵיק.
human_translation: a Hebrew maidservant serves neither the brother nor the daughter. From where is this matter Rabbi Padda said: As the verse states “And also to your maidservant you shall do likewise” The verse juxtaposes to a pierced Just as a pierced serves neither the son nor the daughter, so too a Hebrew maidservant serves neither the son nor the daughter. And this “And also to your maidservant you shall do likewise,” come this requires it for that which is taught “And also to your maidservant you shall do likewise,” to grant a severance gift.
llm_translation: Hebrew maidservant does not work neither the son nor the daughter. What is the reason? Rabbi Pedah said: As the verse says, "And also to your maidservant you shall do likewise" - the Torah equated her to the Canaanite slave, just as the Canaanite slave does not work neither the son nor the daughter, so too the Hebrew maidservant does not work neither the son nor the daughter. And why did the verse come to this? Because it is necessary for what was taught in a Baraita: "And also to your maidservant you shall do likewise" - to provide for her.

hebrew_text: אַתָּה אוֹמֵר לְהֶעֱנֵיק, אוֹ אֵינוֹ אֶלָּא לִרְצִיעָה? כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר ״וְאִם אָמֹר יֹאמַר הָעֶבֶד״ – ״[הָעֶבֶד]״ וְלֹא אָמָה הָעִבְרִיָּה. (הֲרֵי רְצִיעָה אָמוּר),
human_translation: you say to grant a severance gift or is it only piercing When it says “But if the slave shall say” but a Hebrew maidservant cannot, piercing is stated
llm_translation: You say to strangle, or is it only to tear? When he says "and if the slave shall say," - "the slave" and not the Hebrew maidservant. (Behold, it is said to tear).

hebrew_text: הָא מָה אֲנִי מְקַיֵּים ״וְאַף לַאֲמָתְךָ תַּעֲשֶׂה כֵּן״ – לְהֶעֱנֵיק! אִם כֵּן נִכְתּוֹב קְרָא: ״לַאֲמָתְךָ כֵּן״, מַאי ״תַּעֲשֶׂה״? שָׁמְעַתְּ מִינַּהּ תַּרְתֵּי.
human_translation: How do I realize “And also to your maidservant you shall do likewise”? to grant a severance gift If so, let the verse write To your maidservant likewise. What “You shall do”? Draw two conclusions from
llm_translation: The Gemara asks: "How do I fulfill 'and you shall do likewise to your maidservant' - to support her! If so, it should have been written: 'to your maidservant likewise,' what is 'you shall do'? Learn two from it."

hebrew_text: הַנִּרְצָע וְהַנִּמְכָּר לְנׇכְרִי אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵד לֹא אֶת הַבֵּן וְלֹא אֶת הַבַּת. נִרְצָע? דִּכְתִיב: ״וְרָצַע אֲדֹנָיו אֶת אׇזְנוֹ בַּמַּרְצֵעַ וַעֲבָדוֹ לְעֹלָם״ – וְלֹא אֶת הַבֵּן וְאֶת הַבַּת. נִמְכָּר לְנׇכְרִי מִנַּיִן? אָמַר חִזְקִיָּה: אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְחִשַּׁב עִם קֹנֵהוּ״ – וְלֹא עִם יוֹרְשֵׁי קוֹנֵהוּ.
human_translation: a pierced and one sold to a gentile serve neither the son nor the daughter. a pierced as it is written: “And his master shall pierce his ear with an awl, and he shall serve him forever” but not the son or the daughter. From where sold to a gentile? Ḥizkiyya says the verse states “And he shall reckon with his purchaser” but not to the heirs of his purchaser.
llm_translation: The one who is castrated and the one who is sold to a non-Jew does not work neither the son nor the daughter. Castrated? As it is written: "And his master shall bore his ear through with an awl, and he shall serve him forever" - but not the son and the daughter. Sold to a non-Jew, from where? Hezekiah said: Scripture says: "And he shall reckon with him that bought him" - but not with the heirs of the one who bought him.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: דְּבַר תּוֹרָה נׇכְרִי יוֹרֵשׁ אֶת אָבִיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְחִשַּׁב עִם קֹנֵהוּ״ – וְלֹא עִם יוֹרְשֵׁי קוֹנֵהוּ. מִכְּלָל דְּאִית לֵיהּ יוֹרְשִׁים. גֵּר אֶת הַנׇּכְרִי – אֵינוֹ מִדִּבְרֵי תוֹרָה, אֶלָּא מִדִּבְרֵי סוֹפְרִים.
human_translation: Rava says: By Torah law a gentile inherits his father, as it is stated “And he shall reckon with his purchaser,” but not with his purchaser’s heirs. by inference has heirs. by Torah law a convert does not gentile, Rather, by rabbinic law.
llm_translation: Rava said: A non-Jewish son inherits his father's Torah matters, as it is stated: "And he shall reckon with him that bought him" (Leviticus 25:49) - and not with the heirs of the one who bought him. From this, it can be inferred that he has heirs. A convert who marries a non-Jew - his words are not from the Torah, but from the words of the Scribes.

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן: גֵּר וְנׇכְרִי שֶׁיָּרְשׁוּ אֶת אֲבִיהֶם נׇכְרִי, גֵּר יָכוֹל לוֹמַר לְנׇכְרִי טוֹל אַתָּה עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה וַאֲנִי מָעוֹת, טוֹל אַתָּה יַיִן נֶסֶךְ וַאֲנִי פֵּירוֹת. מִשֶּׁבָּאוּ לִרְשׁוּת גֵּר – אָסוּר.
human_translation: As we learned a convert and a gentile who inherited from their gentile father, the convert can say to the gentile: You take idol worship and I money; you take wine a libation and I produce. once they have come into the convert’s possession, prohibited
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: If a convert and a non-Jew inherit their father, the non-Jew inherits as a non-Jew. The convert could say to the non-Jew, "You take foreign worship and I will take money, you take wine libations and I will take produce." Once they come into the possession of the convert - it is prohibited.

hebrew_text: וְאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, כִּי לֹא בָאוּ לִרְשׁוּתוֹ נָמֵי – כִּי שָׁקֵיל חִילּוּפֵי עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה הוּא דְּקָא שָׁקֵיל!
human_translation: And if it would enter your mind by Torah law, it when have not come into his possession as well, when he takes he takes exchanged for idol worship.
llm_translation: And if it enters your mind that it is from the Torah, for they did not come into his domain - for he took the exchange of foreign service, that is what he took!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: מִדְּרַבָּנַן, גְּזֵירָה הוּא דַּעֲבוּד רַבָּנַן שֶׁמָּא יַחְזוֹר לְסוֹרוֹ. תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים – כְּשֶׁיָּרְשׁוּ, אֲבָל כְּשֶׁנִּשְׁתַּתְּפוּ – אָסוּר.
human_translation: Rather, by rabbinic law, a decree that the Sages instituted lest he return to his wayward path [ suro ]. This is also taught In what is this statement said? when they inherited. But when formed a partnership, it is prohibited
llm_translation: Rather: from the Sages, it is a decree of Rabbinic enactment lest one come to smooth it out. It was also taught likewise: In what case are these words said? - When they inherited, but when they intermingled - it is prohibited.

hebrew_text: נׇכְרִי אֶת הַגֵּר, וְגֵר אֶת הַגֵּר – אֵינוֹ לֹא מִדִּבְרֵי תוֹרָה וְלֹא מִדִּבְרֵי סוֹפְרִים. דִּתְנַן: לָוָה מָעוֹת מִן הַגֵּר שֶׁנִּתְגַּיְּירוּ בָּנָיו עִמּוֹ – לֹא יַחֲזִיר לְבָנָיו. וְאִם הֶחֱזִיר – אֵין רוּחַ חֲכָמִים נוֹחָה הֵימֶנּוּ.
human_translation: By Torah law and by rabbinic law a gentile does not from a convert, nor a convert from a convert. As we learned borrowed money from a convert whose sons converted with him, he does not return to sons, And if he return the Sages are not pleased with him.
llm_translation: A non-Jew marries a convert, and a convert marries a convert - this law is neither from the words of the Torah nor from the words of the Scribes. For it was taught: If a convert lent money to his sons who converted with him - he shall not return the money to his sons. And if he returned the money - the spirit of the wise does not rest with him.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא רוּחַ חֲכָמִים נוֹחָה הֵימֶנּוּ! לָא קַשְׁיָא, כָּאן שֶׁהוֹרָתוֹ וְלֵידָתוֹ שֶׁלֹּא בִּקְדוּשָּׁה,
human_translation: But isn’t it taught the Sages are pleased with him? not difficult. Here, whose conception and birth were not in sanctity
llm_translation: And it was taught: "The spirit of the sages rests upon him!" It is not difficult, here where his conception and birth were not in holiness.

hebrew_text: וְכָאן שֶׁהוֹרָתוֹ שֶׁלֹּא בִּקְדוּשָּׁה, וְלֵידָתוֹ בִּקְדוּשָּׁה.
human_translation: And here where he was not conceived in sanctity, and his birth was in sanctity,
llm_translation: And here, his conception not in holiness, and his birth in holiness.

hebrew_text: רַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָבִין אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: נׇכְרִי יוֹרֵשׁ אֶת אָבִיו דְּבַר תּוֹרָה, דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי יְרֻשָּׁה לְעֵשָׂו נָתַתִּי אֶת הַר שֵׂעִיר״. וְדִלְמָא יִשְׂרָאֵל מְשׁוּמָּד שָׁאנֵי? אֶלָּא מֵהָכָא: ״כִּי לִבְנֵי לוֹט נָתַתִּי אֶת עָר יְרֻשָּׁה״.
human_translation: Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin Rabbi Yoḥanan says: By Torah law a gentile inherits his father, as it is written: “Because I have given mount Seir to Esau as an inheritance” But perhaps is different an apostate Jew? Rather, from here: “Because I have given Ar to the children of Lot as an inheritance”
llm_translation: Rav Chiya bar Avin said, Rabbi Yochanan said: A non-Jew inherits his father in matters of Torah, as it is written: "For I have given the hill of Seir as a possession to Esau." And perhaps Israel is despised? Rather, from here: "For I have given the city of Ar as a possession to the sons of Lot."

hebrew_text: וְרַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָבִין, מַאי טַעְמָא לָא אָמַר כְּרָבָא? מִי כְּתִיב ״וְחִשַּׁב עִם קֹנֵהוּ וְלֹא עִם יוֹרְשֵׁי קוֹנֵהוּ״?
human_translation: And Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin, what is the reason did not state in accordance with Rava, Is it written And he shall reckon with his purchaser and not with the heirs of his purchaser?
llm_translation: Rav Chiya bar Avin, what is the reason he did not say like Rava? As it is written, "And he shall reckon with him that bought him, according to the time that he was sold to him, and it shall be with him."

hebrew_text: וְרָבָא, מַאי טַעְמָא לָא אָמַר כְּרַב חִיָּיא בַּר אָבִין? מִשּׁוּם כְּבוֹדוֹ דְּאַבְרָהָם שָׁאנֵי.
human_translation: And Rava, what is the reason did not state in accordance with Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin? due to the honor of Abraham is different.
llm_translation: Rava, what reason is there that he did not say like Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin? Because of the honor of Abraham, it is different.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: יֵשׁ בָּעִבְרִי שֶׁאֵין בָּעִבְרִיָּה, וְיֵשׁ בָּעִבְרִיָּה שֶׁאֵין בָּעִבְרִי. יֵשׁ בָּעִבְרִי שֶׁהוּא יוֹצֵא בְּשָׁנִים, וּבַיּוֹבֵל, וּבְמִיתַת הָאָדוֹן – מַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בָּעִבְרִיָּה, וְיֵשׁ בָּעִבְרִיָּה, שֶׁהֲרֵי עִבְרִיָּה יוֹצְאָה בְּסִימָנִין וְאֵינָהּ נִמְכֶּרֶת וְנִשְׁנֵית, וּמַפְדִּין אוֹתָהּ, בְּעַל כּוֹרְחוֹ, מַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בָּעִבְרִי.
human_translation: The Sages taught: There are of a Hebrew that do not to a Hebrew there are of a Hebrew that do not to a Hebrew There are in a Hebrew as he leaves through years, and through the Jubilee and through the death of the master, which is not the case for a Hebrew And there are in a Hebrew as a Hebrew leaves through signs and not sold for a second time, and one can redeem her against his will, which is not the case for a Hebrew
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: There is in Hebrew that which is not in Aramaic, and there is in Aramaic that which is not in Hebrew. There is in Hebrew that is released in years, and in the Jubilee, and in the death of the master - that which is not so in Aramaic. And there is in Aramaic, for Aramaic is released with marks and is not sold or exchanged, and one may redeem it at will, which is not so in Hebrew.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: יֵשׁ בָּעִבְרִי שֶׁאֵין בָּעִבְרִיָּה. וּרְמִינְהִי: יְתֵירָה עָלָיו אָמָה הָעִבְרִיָּה, שֶׁקּוֹנָה עַצְמָהּ בְּסִימָנִין! אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: כְּגוֹן שֶׁיְּעָדָה.
human_translation: The Master said There are of a Hebrew that do not to a Hebrew And raises a contradiction A Hebrew maidservant has more than him, as she acquires herself through signs Rav Sheshet said: where designated her
llm_translation: Master said: There is in Hebrew that which is not in Aramaic. And raise a contradiction: An extra cubit is upon him in Aramaic, for she acquires herself with signs! Rav Sheshet said: For example, that she was designated.

hebrew_text: יְעָדָה, פְּשִׁיטָא! גִּיטָּא בָּעֲיָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא לָא (לִיבְטְלָה) [לִיבְטְלָן] הִילְכָתָא מִינַּהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן. אִי הָכִי, אַמַּאי יוֹצְאָה בְּסִימָנִין? הָכִי קָאָמַר: אִם לֹא יְעָדָה, יוֹצְאָה אַף בְּסִימָנִין.
human_translation: he designated her, it is obvious requires a bill of divorce. lest you say the halakha is not nullified with regard to her, teaches us If so, why does she leave through signs This is what is saying: If he did not designate her, she leaves also through signs
llm_translation: Yi'adah, peshita! Gitta ba'aya! Mahu d'teima la (livtela) livtalan hilchata minah, ka mashma lan. Iy hakhi, ammai yotz'ah b'simanin? Hakhi ka'amar: Im lo yi'adah, yotz'ah af b'simanin.

hebrew_text: וְאֵינָהּ נִמְכֶּרֶת וְנִשְׁנֵית. מִכְּלַל דְּעֶבֶד עִבְרִי נִמְכָּר וְנִשְׁנֶה? וְהָתַנְיָא: ״בִּגְנֵבָתוֹ״ – וְלֹא בִּכְפֵילוֹ. ״בִּגְנֵיבָתוֹ״ – וְלֹא בִּזְמָמוֹ. ״בִּגְנֵיבָתוֹ״ – כֵּיוָן שֶׁנִּמְכַּר פַּעַם אַחַת שׁוּב אִי אַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לְמוֹכְרוֹ.
human_translation: And not sold a second time. From the fact a Hebrew slave can be sold a second time. But isn’t it taught for his theft” but not for his double payment? “for his theft” But not for his conspiring testimony. “for his theft” once he has been sold one time you may not sell him again.
llm_translation: "And it is not sold and repeated. From the inference that a Hebrew slave is sold and repeated? And it was taught: 'In his theft' - and not in his doubling. 'In his theft' - and not in his scheming. 'In his theft' - once he has been sold, you are no longer permitted to sell him."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: לָא קַשְׁיָא, כָּאן בִּגְנֵיבָה אַחַת, כָּאן בִּשְׁתֵּי גְּנֵיבוֹת.
human_translation: Rava said: not difficult. Here, to one theft, There, two thefts,
llm_translation: Rava said: It is not difficult, here in the case of one theft, here in the case of two thefts.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: ״בִּגְנֵיבָתוֹ״ – טוּבָא מַשְׁמַע! אֶלָּא אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לָא קַשְׁיָא, כָּאן בְּאָדָם אֶחָד, כָּאן בִּשְׁנֵי בְּנֵי אָדָם.
human_translation: Abaye said to “for his theft” indicates many Rather, Abaye said: not difficult. Here, to one person. There, to two people.
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: "In his theft" - good implication! Rather Abaye said: It is not difficult, here in the case of one person, here in the case of two people.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: גְּנֵיבוֹ אֶלֶף, וְשָׁוֶה חֲמֵשׁ מֵאוֹת – נִמְכָּר וְחוֹזֵר וְנִמְכָּר. גְּנֵיבוֹ חֲמֵשׁ מֵאוֹת, וְשָׁוֶה אֶלֶף – אֵינוֹ נִמְכָּר כְּלָל. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אִם הָיָה גְּנֵיבוֹ כְּנֶגֶד מִמְכָּרוֹ – נִמְכָּר, וְאִם לָאו – אֵינוֹ נִמְכָּר.
human_translation: The Sages taught: property he stole one thousand and is worth five hundred, he is sold and sold again. property he stole five hundred is worth one thousand, he is not sold at all. Rabbi Eliezer says: If property he stole was equal to sold, he is sold; and if not, he is not sold.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: If one stole a thousand and it was worth five hundred - it is sold, then returned and sold again. If one stole five hundred and it was worth a thousand - it is not sold at all. Rabbi Eliezer says: If his theft matched his sale - it is sold, but if not - it is not sold.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: בְּהָא זְכָנְהוּ רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר לְרַבָּנַן, דְּמַאי שְׁנָא גְּנֵיבוֹ חֲמֵשׁ מֵאוֹת וְשָׁוֶה אֶלֶף דְּאֵין נִמְכָּר, דְּנִמְכַּר כּוּלּוֹ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, וְלֹא חֶצְיוֹ, הָכִי נָמֵי: נִמְכַּר בִּגְנֵיבָתוֹ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא וְלֹא נִמְכַּר בַּחֲצִי גְנֵיבָתוֹ.
human_translation: Rava said: In this Rabbi Eliezer triumphed over the Rabbis, as what is different property he stole five hundred and he is worth one thousand that he is not sold? the Merciful One states that he is sold in his entirety, and not part of him. So too, The Merciful One states he is sold for his theft, and he is not sold for part of his theft.
llm_translation: Rava said: In this case, Rabbi Eliezer acquired it for the Rabbis, for what is the difference between stealing five hundred and it being worth a thousand that it is not sold? If it is all sold, the Merciful One said, and not half of it, so too here: if it is sold through his theft, the Merciful One said, and not sold through half of his theft.

hebrew_text: וּמַפְדִּין אוֹתָהּ בְּעַל כׇּרְחוֹ. סְבַר רָבָא לְמֵימַר בְּעַל כֻּרְחֵיהּ דְּאָדוֹן. אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: מַאי נִיהוּ – דְּכָתֵבְנָא לֵיהּ שְׁטָרָא אַדְּמֶיהָ? אַמַּאי? נָקֵיט מַרְגָּנִיתָא בִּידֵיהּ, יָהֵיבְנָא לֵיהּ חַסְפָּא?
human_translation: And one can redeem against his will. Rava thought to say against the will of the master, Abaye said to him: What is that one writes a document to him for her value, Why is holding a pearl [ marganita ] in his hand one gives him a shard
llm_translation: And redeem her by her husband by force. Rava thought to say by her husband of her master. Abaye said to him: What is the reason - that we write for her a bill of divorce? Why? She took a handkerchief in her hand, should we give her money?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: בְּעַל כֻּרְחֵיהּ דְּאָב, מִשּׁוּם פְּגַם מִשְׁפָּחָה. אִי הָכִי, עֶבֶד עִבְרִי נָמֵי, נִכְפִּינְהוּ לִבְנֵי מִשְׁפָּחָה מִשּׁוּם פְּגַם מִשְׁפָּחָה! הָדַר אָזֵיל וּמְזַבֵּין נַפְשֵׁיהּ.
human_translation: Rather, Abaye said: against the will of father, due to the family flaw, If so, one should force the family of a Hebrew slave also, due to the family flaw. he will go back and sell himself
llm_translation: Rather, Abaye said: In the case of a Baal Kurchei of Av, due to a blemish in the family. If so, only a Hebrew slave, they should have hidden him from the members of the family due to a blemish in the family! He then went and took his own life.

hebrew_text: הָכָא נָמֵי הָדַר אָזֵיל וּמְזַבֵּין לַהּ! הָא קָתָנֵי: אֵינָהּ נִמְכֶּרֶת וְנִשְׁנֵית. וּמַנִּי – רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא: מוֹכֵר אָדָם אֶת בִּתּוֹ לְאִישׁוּת וְשׁוֹנֶה, לְשִׁפְחוּת וְשׁוֹנֶה, לְאִישׁוּת אַחַר שִׁפְחוּת, אֲבָל לֹא לְשִׁפְחוּת אַחַר אִישׁוּת. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאֵין אָדָם מוֹכֵר אֶת בִּתּוֹ לְשִׁפְחוּת אַחַר אִישׁוּת כָּךְ אֵין אָדָם מוֹכֵר אֶת בִּתּוֹ לְשִׁפְחוּת אַחַר שִׁפְחוּת.
human_translation: Here too, might go back and sell her is taught: is not sold a second time. And whose It is Rabbi Shimon, as it is taught One can sell, his daughter in marriage and again into slavery and again, for marriage, after slavery. But cannot slavery after marriage. Rabbi Shimon says: Just as a person cannot sell his daughter into slavery after marriage, so too, a person cannot sell his daughter into slavery after slavery.
llm_translation: Here is the translation of the Talmudic text into English: Here, it is taught: "He goes and sells her!" This is what is taught: "She is not sold and exchanged." And who is the authority? Rabbi Shimon. As it was taught: A man may sell his daughter for betrothal and she is exchanged, for servitude and she is exchanged, for betrothal after servitude, but not for servitude after betrothal. Rabbi Shimon says: Just as a man does not sell his daughter for servitude after betrothal, so too, a man does not sell his daughter for servitude after servitude.

hebrew_text: וּבִפְלוּגְתָּא דְּהָנֵי תַּנָּאֵי דְּתַנְיָא: ״בְּבִגְדוֹ בָּהּ״ –
human_translation: And in the dispute these tanna’im , as it is taught
llm_translation: And in the dispute of those Tannaim as it was taught: "In his garment in it" -

hebrew_text: כֵּיוָן שֶׁפֵּירַשׂ טַלִּיתוֹ עָלֶיהָ, שׁוּב אֵין רַשַּׁאי לְמוֹכְרָהּ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: ״בְּבִגְדוֹ בָּהּ״ – כֵּיוָן שֶׁבָּגַד בָּהּ, שׁוּב אֵין רַשַּׁאי לְמוֹכְרָהּ.
human_translation: once has spread his garment over her, may no longer sell her. the statement of Rabbi Akiva, Rabbi Eliezer says: “ Bevigdo vah ” since dealt deceitfully [ bagad ] with her he cannot sell her again.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Once he spread his garment upon it, he may not sell it again, the words of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Eliezer says: "In his garment within it" - once he clothed himself with it, he may not sell it again.

hebrew_text: בְּמַאי קָמִיפַּלְגִי? רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר סָבַר: יֵשׁ אֵם לַמָּסוֹרֶת, וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא סָבַר: יֵשׁ אֵם לַמִּקְרָא, וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן סָבַר: יֵשׁ אֵם לַמִּקְרָא וְלַמָּסוֹרֶת.
human_translation: With regard to what do disagree? Rabbi Eliezer maintains the tradition authoritative, And Rabbi Akiva maintains vocalization is authoritative, And Rabbi Shimon maintains vocalization and the tradition authoritative.
llm_translation: With what do they disagree? Rabbi Eliezer holds: There is a mother for tradition, and Rabbi Akiva holds: There is a mother for scripture, and Rabbi Shimon holds: There is a mother for scripture and for tradition.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַבָּה בַּר אֲבוּהּ: יִעוּד נִישּׂוּאִין עוֹשֶׂה, אוֹ אֵירוּסִין עוֹשֶׂה? נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ לְיוֹרְשָׁהּ, וְלִיטַמֵּא לָהּ, וּלְהָפֵר נְדָרֶיהָ. מַאי?
human_translation: Rabba bar Avuh raises a dilemma: designation effect marriage or effect betrothal? practical difference whether he inherits her and become impure to her and nullify her vows What
llm_translation: Ba'ei Ravva bar Avuh: Yi'ud nis'u'in oseh, o eirusin oseh? Nafka minah leyor'shah, v'litamei lah, ulehafair nedarieha. Mai? Ravva bar Avuh asked: Does betrothal create marriage, or does engagement create marriage? It emerges to disqualify her as an heir, and to render her impure, and to annul her vows. What is the ruling?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: ״בְּבִגְדוֹ בָּהּ״ – כֵּיוָן שֶׁפֵּירַשׂ טַלִּיתוֹ עָלֶיהָ שׁוּב אֵינוֹ רַשַּׁאי לְמוֹכְרָהּ. זַבּוֹנֵי הוּא דְּלָא מְזַבֵּין לַהּ, הָא יַעוֹדֵי מְיַיעֵד לַהּ, וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ נִישּׂוּאִין עוֹשֶׂה, כֵּיוָן דְּנִישֵּׂאת שׁוּב אֵין לְאָבִיהָ רְשׁוּת בָּהּ! אֶלָּא לָאו שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ אֵירוּסִין עוֹשֶׂה.
human_translation: Come hear “ Bevigdo vah ” Once has spread his garment over her, may no longer sell her. cannot sell her can designate her And if you say effects marriage, once she is married her father no longer has authority over her. Rather, not learn from this effects betrothal?
llm_translation: "Come and hear: 'In his garment in her' - once he has explained his cloak upon her, he is no longer permitted to sell her. This is the opinion of those who do not sell her, but those who betroth her, and if you say betrothal is marriage, once he has betrothed her, her father no longer has authority over her! Rather, it is not so; betrothal does not make her a married woman."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: הָכָא בְּקִידּוּשִׁין דְּעָלְמָא קָאֵי. וְהָכִי קָאָמַר: כֵּיוָן שֶׁמְּסָרָהּ אָבִיהָ לְמִי שֶׁנִּתְחַיֵּיב בִּשְׁאֵרָהּ כְּסוּתָהּ וְעוֹנָתָהּ – שׁוּב אֵין יָכוֹל לְמוֹכְרָהּ.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said Here, dealing with ordinary betrothal And this is what is saying: Since her father gave her, to one who is obligated to her food, her clothing, and her conjugal rights, he can no longer sell her.
llm_translation: Rav Nachman son of Yitzchak said: Here in the matter of betrothal, it stands. And thus he said: Once her father has handed her over to one who is obligated in her other aspects, her clothing and her maintenance - he cannot retract and sell her.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אֵין מוֹכְרָהּ לִקְרוֹבִים. מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אָמְרוּ: מוֹכְרָהּ לִקְרוֹבִים. וְשָׁוִין שֶׁמּוֹכְרָהּ אַלְמָנָה לְכֹהֵן גָּדוֹל, גְּרוּשָׁה וַחֲלוּצָה לְכֹהֵן הֶדְיוֹט.
human_translation: Come hear: cannot sell to relatives They said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: He can sell her to relatives, And they agree that he can sell her to a High Priest a widow, to a common priest a divorcée or a yevama who performed ḥalitza [ ḥalutza ].
llm_translation: Come and hear: One does not sell it to relatives. Because of Rabbi Eliezer they said: One sells it to relatives. And they are equal when she sells it, a widow to a high priest, a divorced woman and a redeemed woman to an ordinary priest.

hebrew_text: הַאי אַלְמָנָה הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? אִילֵּימָא דְּקַדִּישׁ נַפְשַׁהּ, אַלְמָנָה קָרֵי לַהּ? וְאֶלָּא דְּקַדְּשַׁהּ אָבִיהָ. מִי מָצֵי מְזַבֵּין לַהּ? וְהָא אֵין אָדָם מוֹכֵר אֶת בִּתּוֹ לְשִׁפְחוּת אַחַר אִישׁוּת.
human_translation: What are the circumstances of this widow? If we say that betrothed herself she called a widow? Rather, that her father betrothed her can he sell her? But a person cannot sell his daughter into slavery after marriage.
llm_translation: This widow, how is her value? If you say because she consecrated herself, she is called a widow? Rather, it is because her father consecrated her. Who can offer her sacrifices? But is it not the case that a man does not sell his daughter into servitude after marriage.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב עַמְרָם אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: הָכָא בְּקִדּוּשֵׁי יִעוּד, וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה דְּאָמַר: מָעוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנוֹת לָאו לְקִידּוּשִׁין נִיתְּנוּ. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ נִישּׂוּאִין עוֹשֶׂה, כֵּיוָן שֶׁנִּישֵּׂאת שׁוּב אֵין לְאָבִיהָ רְשׁוּת בָּהּ!
human_translation: And Rav Amram says Rabbi Yitzḥak says: Here, to betrothal of designation, and in accordance with Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who says: The original money was not given for betrothal And if you say effects marriage, once she is married her father no longer has authority over her.
llm_translation: And Rav Amram said in the name of Rabbi Yitzchak: Here we are dealing with betrothal gifts, and do not follow the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, the son of Rabbi Yehuda, who said: The initial gifts were not given for betrothal. And if you say marriage makes the gifts - once she marries, her father no longer has authority over her!

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא מַאי, אֵירוּסִין עוֹשֶׂה? – וְשָׁוִין שֶׁמּוֹכְרָהּ?! הָא אֵין אָדָם מוֹכֵר אֶת בִּתּוֹ לְשִׁפְחוּת אַחַר אִישׁוּת! אֶלָּא מַאי אִית לָךְ לְמֵימַר: שָׁאנֵי אֵירוּסִין דִּידַהּ מֵאֵירוּסִין דְּאָבִיהָ? – אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא נִישּׂוּאִין עוֹשֶׂה, שָׁאנֵי נִישּׂוּאִין דִּידַהּ מִנִּישּׂוּאִין דְּאָבִיהָ.
human_translation: Rather, what effects betrothal? And they agree that he can sell her? a person cannot sell his daughter into slavery after matrimony. Rather, what have you to say? Betrothal by her is different from betrothal by her father. even you say effects marriage, marriage by her is different from marriage by her father.
llm_translation: And rather what, what does betrothal accomplish? - And they are equal for she sells it?! Behold, a man does not sell his daughter into servitude after betrothal! Rather, what do you have to say: Is the betrothal of hers different from the betrothal of her father? - Even if you say that marriage accomplishes, it is because her marriage is different from the marriage of her father.

hebrew_text: הַאי מַאי? בִּשְׁלָמָא אֵירוּסִין מֵאֵירוּסִין שָׁאנֵי, אֶלָּא נִישּׂוּאִין מִנִּישּׂוּאִין,
human_translation: What this Granted, betrothal is different from betrothal, But marriage to marriage,
llm_translation: This what? In Shlama, betrothals from betrothals differ, but marriages from marriages.

hebrew_text: מִי שָׁאנֵי?
human_translation: is different?
llm_translation: Who is wealthy?

hebrew_text: וּלְרַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק דְּאָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מָעוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנוֹת לְקִידּוּשִׁין נִיתְּנוּ, בְּמַאי מוֹקֵים לַהּ? מוֹקֵים לַהּ כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר דְּאָמַר: לְשִׁפְחוּת אַחַר שִׁפְחוּת הוּא דְּלָא מָצֵי מְזַבֵּין לַהּ, אֲבָל לְשִׁפְחוּת אַחַר אִישׁוּת – מָצֵי מְזַבֵּין לַהּ.
human_translation: And according to Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak, who says even to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, the original money was given for betrothal, in accordance with whose he establish He establishes it in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer, who says: It is for slavery after slavery that he is not able to sell her, but he is able to sell her into slavery after marriage.
llm_translation: And for Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak who said: Even according to Rabbi Yosei, the son of Rabbi Yehuda, the initial ma'ot for kiddushin were given, with what are they established for her? They are established for her like Rabbi Eliezer who said: For a maidservant after a maidservant, one cannot consecrate for her, but for a maidservant after marriage - one can consecrate for her.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: מַהוּ שֶׁמְּיַיעֵד אָדָם לִבְנוֹ קָטָן? ״בְּנוֹ״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, בְּנוֹ כָּל דְּהוּ, אוֹ דִילְמָא בְּנוֹ דּוּמְיָא דִידֵיהּ, מָה הוּא גָּדוֹל – אַף בְּנוֹ גָּדוֹל?
human_translation: Reish Lakish raises a dilemma: that a person can designate for his minor son, what is his son” the Merciful One states any son, Or perhaps his son similar to him: Just as he is an adult man, so too, his son an adult man.
llm_translation: Inquiry of Reish Lakish: What is the age at which a person designates his small son? "His son," the Merciful One said, his son in any case, or perhaps his son who resembles him, if he is big - even his son is big?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: תָּא שְׁמַע: ״אִישׁ״ – פְּרָט לְקָטָן. ״אֲשֶׁר יִנְאַף אֶת אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ״ – פְּרָט לְאֵשֶׁת קָטָן. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ מְיַיעֵד, אִם כֵּן מָצִינוּ אִישׁוּת לְקָטָן.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: Come hear “man” to exclude a minor “who commits adultery with the wife of another man” to exclude the wife of a minor, And if you say designate we find marriage for a minor.
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira said: Come and hear: "man" - excluding a minor. "who commits adultery with a man's wife" - excluding a minor's wife. And if you say it is referring to betrothal, then we have found betrothal for a minor.

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא מַאי, אֵינוֹ מְיַיעֵד? אַמַּאי קָא מְמַעֵט לֵיהּ קְרָא? תִּיפְשׁוֹט מִינַּהּ דִּמְיַיעֵד. אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: הָכָא בְּיָבָם בֶּן תֵּשַׁע שָׁנִים וְיוֹם אֶחָד הַבָּא עַל יְבִמְתּוֹ עָסְקִינַן,
human_translation: But rather, what cannot designate why does the verse exclude him? resolve from here that one can designate Rav Ashi said: here, we are dealing with a yavam nine years and one day old who engaged in sexual intercourse with his yevama ,
llm_translation: And rather what, is he not designated? Why does the verse minimize it? Learn from it that he is designated. Rav Ashe said: Here we are dealing with a yavam who is nine years and one day old who engages with his yevamah.

hebrew_text: דְּמִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא חַזְיָא לֵיהּ, מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: כֵּיוָן דְּמִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא חַזְיָא לֵיהּ וּבִיאָתוֹ בִּיאָה, הַבָּא עָלֶיהָ מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּאֵשֶׁת אִישׁ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: that by Torah law is fit for him. lest you say: Since by Torah law she is fit for him, and his sexual intercourse intercourse; one who engages in intercourse with her becomes liable for a married woman. teaches us
llm_translation: From the Torah, see to it, what do you say: since from the Torah see to it and his coming, a man who has relations with her is liable to the punishment of a married woman, it is heard to us.

hebrew_text: מַאי הָוֵי עֲלַהּ? תָּא שְׁמַע, אָמַר רַבִּי אַיְיבוּ אָמַר רַבִּי יַנַּאי: אֵין יִעוּד אֶלָּא בְּגָדוֹל, אֵין יִעוּד אֶלָּא מִדַּעַת. תַּרְתֵּי? ״מָה טַעַם״ קָאָמַר. מָה טַעַם אֵין יִעוּד אֶלָּא בְּגָדוֹל – לְפִי שֶׁאֵין יִעוּד אֶלָּא מִדַּעַת.
human_translation: what was about Come hear, Rabbi Aivu says Rabbi Yannai says: Designation applies only to an adult man, designation applies only with consent. two is saying: What is the reason, what is the reason designation applies only to an adult man? because designation applies only with consent.
llm_translation: What is the meaning of "עֲלַהּ"? Come and hear, Rabbi Ayyivu said in the name of Rabbi Yannai: Destiny only applies to the great, destiny only applies to those with knowledge. Two? "What is the reason," he is saying. What is the reason destiny only applies to the great? Because destiny only applies to those with knowledge.

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: מַאי מִדַּעַת – מִדַּעַת דִּידַהּ. דְּתָנֵי אַבָּיֵי בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: ״אֲשֶׁר לֹא יְעָדָהּ״ – מְלַמֵּד שֶׁצָּרִיךְ לְיַעֲדָהּ.
human_translation: And if you wish, say What With consent? with her consent. As Abaye, son of Rabbi Abbahu, taught: “who did not designate her [ ye’adah ]” teaches that he is required to inform her [ ya’adah ].
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: What is the meaning of "mid'adatah" - from our own knowledge. For Abaye, the son of Rabbi Avahu, taught: "which he did not designate" - teaches that one must designate it.

hebrew_text: הוּא תָּנֵי לַהּ, וְהוּא אָמַר לַהּ: בְּקִידּוּשֵׁי יִעוּד, וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה דְּאָמַר: מָעוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנוֹת לָאו לְקִידּוּשִׁין נִיתְּנוּ. רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא לְקִידּוּשִׁין נִיתְּנוּ, שָׁאנֵי הָכָא דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״יְעָדָהּ״.
human_translation: He teaches it and he says it: to betrothal through designation, and in accordance with Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who said: The original money was not given for betrothal. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Even you say was given for betrothal, it is different here, as the Merciful One states “designate her [ ye’adah ].”
llm_translation: He taught her, and he said to her: In the sanctifications of designated funds, and in the dispute of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda who said: The initial funds were not designated for sanctifications. Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: Even if you were to say that the funds were designated for sanctifications, it is different here, as the Merciful One said "her endowment."

hebrew_text: מַאי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? דְּתַנְיָא: ״יְעָדָהּ, וְהֶפְדָּהּ״ – צָרִיךְ שֶׁיְּהֵא שְׁהוּת בַּיּוֹם כְּדֵי פְדִיָּיה.
human_translation: What Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, As it is taught designate her, then he shall let her be redeemed” it is necessary that there must be enough time in the day for redemption.
llm_translation: What is Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda? As it was taught: "He shall designate it, and redeem it" - it is necessary that its designation be during the day, in order to redeem it.

hebrew_text: מִכָּאן אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה: אִם יֵשׁ שְׁהוּת בַּיּוֹם כְּדֵי לַעֲשׂוֹת עִמּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה – מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת, וְאִם לָאו – אֵינָהּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת. אַלְמָא קָסָבַר: מָעוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנוֹת – לָאו לְקִידּוּשִׁין נִיתְּנוּ.
human_translation: From here Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: If there is enough time in the day for her to perform worth one peruta for him, she is betrothed, And if not, she is not betrothed. Apparently, he maintains the original money was not given for betrothal.
llm_translation: From here Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said: If there is a pause during the day sufficient to engage in conversation with him, a perutah's worth - she becomes betrothed, and if not - she does not become betrothed. This implies that he holds: The initial ma'ot were not given for betrothals.

hebrew_text: רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא לְקִידּוּשִׁין נִיתְּנוּ, שָׁאנֵי הָכָא דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״וְהֶפְדָּהּ״.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Even you say was given for betrothal, It is different here, as the Merciful One states then he shall let her be redeemed,”
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: Even if you were to say that they were given for kiddushin, it is different here, as the Merciful One said, "and he redeemed her."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: אוֹמֵר אָדָם לְבִתּוֹ קְטַנָּה ״צְאִי וְקַבְּלִי קִידּוּשַׁיִךְ״, מִדְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: Rava says Rav Naḥman says: A person say to his minor daughter: Go out and accept your betrothal, from that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda
llm_translation: Rava said, Rav Nachman said: A person says to his young daughter, "Go out and accept my sanctification," following Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: לָאו אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מָעוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנוֹת לָאו לְקִידּוּשִׁין נִיתְּנוּ, וְכִי מְשַׁיַּיר בַּהּ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה – הָווּ קִידּוּשֵׁי, הָכָא נָמֵי לָא שְׁנָא.
human_translation: Didn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, say that the original money was not given for betrothal, and if her worth one peruta remains, it is a betrothal? Here too, it is no different,
llm_translation: Not said Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yehuda: The first coins were not given for Kiddushin, and if one leaves in it a Prutah - they are Kiddushin. Here too it is not different.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: הַמְקַדֵּשׁ בְּמִלְוָה שֶׁיֵּשׁ עָלֶיהָ מַשְׁכּוֹן – מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת, מִדְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה. לָאו אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מָעוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנוֹת לָאו לְקִידּוּשִׁין נִיתְּנוּ, הַאי הַלְוָאָה הִיא, וְהִיא גּוּפַהּ מַשְׁכּוֹן הִיא,
human_translation: And Rava says Rav Naḥman says: one who betroths with a loan for which there is collateral, she is betrothed. from that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, Didn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, say that the original money was not given for betrothal? this is a loan, and she herself is the collateral.
llm_translation: And Rava said in the name of Rav Nachman: One who sanctifies with a loan that has collateral on it - it is sanctified, in accordance with Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. Did Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda not say: The initial funds were not given for sanctifications, rather it is a loan, and it itself is the collateral.

hebrew_text: וְכִי מְשַׁיַּיר בַּהּ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה וּמְיַיעֵד – הָווּ קִידּוּשִׁין, הָכָא נָמֵי לָא שְׁנָא.
human_translation: And if her worth one peruta remains, and he designates it is a betrothal. Here too, it is no different,
llm_translation: And if he leaves in it worth a prutah and designates it - it is considered a valid betrothal, here it is not different.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: כֵּיצַד מִצְוַת יִעוּד? אוֹמֵר לָהּ בִּפְנֵי שְׁנַיִם ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת לִי״, ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מְאוֹרֶסֶת לִי״ אֲפִילּוּ בְּסוֹף שֵׁשׁ, וַאֲפִילּוּ סָמוּךְ לִשְׁקִיעַת הַחַמָּה. וְנוֹהֵג בָּהּ מִנְהַג אִישׁוּת וְאֵינוֹ נוֹהֵג בָּהּ מִנְהַג שִׁפְחוּת. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אִם יֵשׁ שְׁהוּת בְּיוֹם כְּדֵי לַעֲשׂוֹת עִמּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה – מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת, וְאִם לָאו – אֵינָהּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת.
human_translation: The Sages taught: How is the mitzva of designation says to her before two You are hereby betrothed [ mekuddeshet ] to me, You are hereby betrothed [ me’oreset ] to me. even at the end of six and even close to sunset And he treats her in the manner of marriage and may not treat her in the manner of slavery. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: If there is enough time in that day for her to perform him worth one peruta , she is betrothed, and if not, she is not betrothed.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: How does the mitzvah of betrothal take place? He says to her in the presence of two witnesses, "Behold, you are consecrated to me," "Behold, you are betrothed to me," even at the end of six hours, and even if it is close to sunset. And one conducts himself with her according to the custom of free women, and does not conduct himself with her according to the custom of slaves. Rabbi Yosei, the son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: If there is enough time during the day to be with her equivalent to a prutah – she is consecrated, and if not – she is not consecrated.

hebrew_text: מָשָׁל לְאוֹמֵר לְאִשָּׁה ״הִתְקַדְּשִׁי לִי מֵעַכְשָׁיו לְאַחַר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם״ וּבָא אַחֵר וְקִידְּשָׁהּ בְּתוֹךְ שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם – שֶׁמְּקוּדֶּשֶׁת לָרִאשׁוֹן. מָשָׁל לְמַאן?
human_translation: a parable to one who says to a woman: Be betrothed to me from now after thirty days, and another man came and betrothed her within thirty days. that she is betrothed to the first According to whom parable
llm_translation: A parable: One who says to a woman, "Be consecrated to me from now until after thirty days," and another comes and consecrates her within thirty days - she is considered consecrated to the first. To whom can this be compared?

hebrew_text: אִילֵימָא מָשָׁל לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה – הָא אִם יֵשׁ שְׁהוּת בְּיוֹם כְּדֵי לַעֲשׂוֹת עִמּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה – מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת, וְאִם לָאו – לֹא!
human_translation: If we say parable is to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, If there is enough time on that day for her to perform him worth one peruta , she is betrothed, and if not, not
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates as follows: "If there is a delay during the day sufficient to perform with him a 'prutah' - she is sanctified, and if not - she is not!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרָבָא: מָשָׁל לְרַבָּנַן. פְּשִׁיטָא!
human_translation: Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said: parable is to the Rabbis, Isn’t it obvious
llm_translation: Rav Ahah, son of Rava, said: A parable to the Rabbis. Obviously!

hebrew_text: מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא, הָא לָא אֲמַר לֵיהּ ״מֵעַכְשָׁיו״, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: lest you say did not say to from now. teaches us
llm_translation: What is the reasoning for saying, "from now on," he is implying to us.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: הַמּוֹכֵר אֶת בִּתּוֹ, וְהָלַךְ וְקִידְּשָׁהּ לְאַחֵר – שִׂיחֵק בָּאָדוֹן, וּמְקוּדֶּשֶׁת לַשֵּׁנִי, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אִם רָצָה לְיַיעֵד – מְיַיעֵד.
human_translation: It is taught another one who sells his daughter and goes and betroths her to another mocks the master, and she is betrothed to the second the statement of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. And the Rabbis say: If wants to designate designate
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: The one who sells his daughter, and then goes and betroths her to another – he jests with the master, and betroths her to a second, the words of Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yehuda. And the Sages say: If he wishes to betroth her – he may betroth her.

hebrew_text: מָשָׁל לָאוֹמֵר לְאִשָּׁה ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת לִי לְאַחַר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם״ וּבָא אַחֵר וְקִידְּשָׁהּ בְּתוֹךְ שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם – שֶׁמְּקוּדֶּשֶׁת לַשֵּׁנִי. מָשָׁל לְמַאן?
human_translation: a parable to one who says to a woman: Be betrothed to me after thirty days, and another man came and betrothed her within thirty days. that she is betrothed to the second According to whom parable
llm_translation: A parable: One who says to a woman, "Behold, you are sanctified to me after thirty days," and another comes and sanctifies her within thirty days - she is sanctified to the second. To whom is this comparable?

hebrew_text: אִילֵּימָא לְרַבָּנַן, הָאָמְרִי רַבָּנַן: אִם רָצָה לְיַיעֵד – מְיַיעֵד!
human_translation: If we say parable is to the Rabbis, don’t the Rabbis say if wants to designate he may designate
llm_translation: If you wish to appoint, appoint!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרָבָא: מָשָׁל לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה. פְּשִׁיטָא!
human_translation: Rather, Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said: parable is to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. Isn’t it obvious
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Acha, son of Rava, said: A parable for Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. It is obvious!

hebrew_text: מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא, הָא לָא אֲמַר לַהּ ״לְאַחַר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם״, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: lest you say he did not say to her After thirty days. teaches us
llm_translation: What is the reasoning? This does not say to her "after thirty days," it implies to us.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: הַמּוֹכֵר אֶת בִּתּוֹ, וּפָסַק עַל מְנָת שֶׁלֹּא לְיַיעֵד – נִתְקַיֵּים הַתְּנַאי, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אִם רָצָה לְיַיעֵד – מְיַיעֵד, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהִתְנָה עַל מַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בַּתּוֹרָה, וְכׇל הַמַּתְנֶה עַל מַה שֶּׁכָּתוּב בַּתּוֹרָה – תְּנָאוֹ בָּטֵל.
human_translation: It is taught another one who sells his daughter and stipulates on the condition that he does not designate the condition stands. the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: If wants to designate he may designate her, because stipulated counter to that which is written in the Torah, And anyone who stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah, his condition is void.
llm_translation: It was taught in another Baraita: One who sells his daughter, and stipulates that he is not designating her for marriage - the condition is fulfilled, the words of Rabbi Meir. And the Sages say: If he wants to designate her - he may designate her, because he stipulated based on what is written in the Torah, and anyone who stipulates based on what is written in the Torah - his stipulation is nullified.

hebrew_text: וּלְרַבִּי מֵאִיר תְּנָאוֹ קַיָּים? וְהָתַנְיָא: הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשָּׁה ״הֲרֵי אַתְּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת לִי עַל מְנָת שֶׁאֵין לְךָ עָלַי שְׁאֵר כְּסוּת וְעוֹנָה״ – הֲרֵי זוֹ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת, וּתְנָאוֹ בָּטֵל, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בְּדָבָר שֶׁבְּמָמוֹן – תְּנָאוֹ קַיָּים.
human_translation: And according to Rabbi Meir, his condition stand But isn’t it taught One who says to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me on the condition that you do not have against me food, clothing, and conjugal rights, she is betrothed and his condition is void; the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: With regard to monetary matters, his condition stands.
llm_translation: And for Rabbi Meir, does his teaching stand? And it was taught: One who says to a woman, "Behold, you are consecrated to me on the condition that you have no claim upon me for sustenance and clothing," - she is consecrated, and his condition is nullified, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: In matters of money - his condition stands.

hebrew_text: אָמַר חִזְקִיָּה: שָׁאנֵי הָכָא, דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״לְאָמָה״ – פְּעָמִים שֶׁאֵינוֹ מוֹכְרָהּ אֶלָּא לְאָמָה בִּלְבָד.
human_translation: Ḥizkiyya said: is different here, as the verse states: as a maidservant” times when he sells her only as a maidservant,
llm_translation: Hezekiah said: This is different here, as the verse says "to her mother" - at times when it is only sold to her mother alone.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן, הַאי ״לְאָמָה״ מַאי עָבְדִי לֵיהּ? הַאי מִיבְּעֵי לְהוּ לְכִדְתַנְיָא: ״לְאָמָה״ – מְלַמֵּד שֶׁמּוֹכְרָהּ לִפְסוּלִים.
human_translation: And the Rabbis, what do they do with this “As a maidservant”? This necessary for them for that which is taught “as a maidservant.” teaches that he can sell her to flawed
llm_translation: The sages, what does this "le'ama" do to it? This teaches that she sold it to disqualified individuals.

hebrew_text: וַהֲלֹא דִּין הוּא: אִם מְקַדְּשָׁהּ לִפְסוּלִים, לֹא יִמְכְּרֶנָּה לִפְסוּלִים? מָה לִמְקַדְּשָׁהּ לִפְסוּלִים, שֶׁכֵּן אָדָם מְקַדֵּשׁ אֶת בִּתּוֹ כְּשֶׁהִיא נַעֲרָה, יִמְכְּרֶנָּה לִפְסוּלִים, שֶׁאֵין אָדָם מוֹכֵר אֶת בִּתּוֹ כְּשֶׁהִיא נַעֲרָה? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לְאָמָה״ – מְלַמֵּד שֶׁמּוֹכְרָהּ לִפְסוּלִין.
human_translation: But not logical inference: If can betroth her to flawed not sell her to flawed what betrothal to flawed a person can betroth his daughter when she is a young woman, he can sell her to flawed as a person cannot sell his daughter when she is a young woman. the verse states “as a maidservant,” teaches that sell her to disqualified people.
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: And isn't this the law: If one consecrates her for disqualified individuals, may he not sell her to disqualified individuals? Just as one consecrates her for disqualified individuals, for a man consecrates his daughter when she is a young girl, may he sell her to disqualified individuals, for a man does not sell his daughter when she is a young girl? The Talmud teaches: "For what reason" - it teaches that one may sell her to disqualified individuals.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אִם לְלַמֵּד שֶׁמּוֹכְרָהּ לִפְסוּלִין, הֲרֵי כְּבָר נֶאֱמַר ״אִם רָעָה בְּעֵינֵי אֲדֹנֶיהָ״ – שֶׁרָעָה בְּנִישּׂוּאֶיהָ. מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לְאָמָה״? מְלַמֵּד שֶׁמּוֹכְרָהּ
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer says: If to teach that he can sell her to flawed as it is already stated: “If she does not please her master, that she is displeasing in her marriage, what the verse states “as a maidservant”? teaches that he can sell her
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer says: If to teach that she sold to disqualified individuals, behold it is already stated "if she is evil in the eyes of her master" - that she is evil in her marriage. What is the teaching to say "to a nation"? It teaches that she sold her.

hebrew_text: לִקְרוֹבִים.
human_translation: to relatives,
llm_translation: Those who are near.

hebrew_text: וַהֲלֹא דִּין הוּא: אִם מוֹכְרָהּ לִפְסוּלִין, לֹא יִמְכְּרֶנָּה לִקְרוֹבִים? מָה לְמוֹכְרָהּ לִפְסוּלִין, שֶׁאִם רָצָה לְיַיעֵד – מְיַיעֵד, יִמְכְּרֶנָּה לִקְרוֹבִים, שֶׁאִם רָצָה לְיַיעֵד – אֵינוֹ מְיַיעֵד? אָמַר קְרָא ״לְאָמָה״ – מְלַמֵּד שֶׁמּוֹכְרָהּ לִקְרוֹבִים.
human_translation: But not logical inference: If he can sell her to flawed not sell her to relatives? what about selling her to flawed that if wants to designate he can designate he can sell her to relatives. where if wants to designate he cannot designate the verse states “as a maidservant,” teaches that he can sell her to relatives.
llm_translation: The text is as follows: Is it not the law: If she sells it to disqualified individuals, should she not sell it to relatives? Why is it that if she sells it to disqualified individuals, if she wishes to designate the item – she may designate it, but if she sells it to relatives, if she wishes to designate it – she may not designate it? The verse says "to a stranger" – this teaches that she sells it to relatives.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי מֵאִיר? לִפְסוּלִין, נָפְקָא לֵיהּ מֵהֵיכָא דְּנָפְקָא לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר. בִּקְרוֹבִים, סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבָּנַן דְּאָמְרִי אֵין מוֹכְרָהּ לִקְרוֹבִים.
human_translation: And Rabbi Meir, He derives flawed from where Rabbi Eliezer derives With regard to relatives, he holds in accordance with the Rabbis, who say he cannot sell her to relatives.
llm_translation: Rabbi Meir? To disqualify, it emerged for him from where it emerged for Rabbi Eliezer. With relatives, he holds like the Rabbis who say, "She does not sell to relatives."

hebrew_text: תָּנֵי חֲדָא: מוֹכְרָהּ לְאָבִיו, וְאֵין מוֹכְרָהּ לִבְנוֹ. וְתַנְיָא אִידַּךְ: אֵין מוֹכְרָהּ לֹא לְאָבִיו וְלֹא לִבְנוֹ. בִּשְׁלָמָא אֵינוֹ מוֹכְרָהּ לֹא לְאָבִיו וְלֹא לִבְנוֹ – כְּרַבָּנַן. אֶלָּא מוֹכְרָהּ לְאָבִיו וְאֵין מוֹכְרָהּ לִבְנוֹ, כְּמַאן?
human_translation: It is taught one One can sell to his father, but he cannot sell her to his son. And it is taught another He cannot sell her to his father nor to his son. Granted, he cannot sell her to his father nor to his son with the Rabbis, But in accordance with whose he can sell her to his father but he cannot sell her to his son?
llm_translation: One taught: She may be sold to her father, but she may not be sold to her son. And it was taught in another Baraita: She may not be sold neither to her father nor to her son. It is understandable that she may not be sold neither to her father nor to her son - according to the Rabbis. Rather, she may be sold to her father, but she may not be sold to her son. According to whom?

hebrew_text: לָא כְּרַבָּנַן וְלָא כְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר! לְעוֹלָם כְּרַבָּנַן, מוֹדוּ רַבָּנַן הֵיכָא דְּאִיכָּא צַד יִעוּד.
human_translation: It is not in accordance with the Rabbis, and it is not in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer, Actually, with the Rabbis. the Rabbis concede where there is a possibility of designation.
llm_translation: Not like Rabbanan and not like Rabbi Eliezer! Always like Rabbanan, the Rabbis concede where there is a side of certainty.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״אִם בְּגַפּוֹ יָבֹא בְּגַפּוֹ יֵצֵא״ – בְּגוּפוֹ נִכְנַס בְּגוּפוֹ יֵצֵא. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: יְחִידִי נִכְנַס יְחִידִי יֵצֵא. מַאי בְּגוּפוֹ נִכְנַס בְּגוּפוֹ יֵצֵא? אָמַר רָבָא: לוֹמַר שֶׁאֵינוֹ יוֹצֵא בְּרָאשֵׁי אֵבָרִים כְּעֶבֶד. אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: הָהוּא – מִ״לֹּא תֵצֵא כְּצֵאת הָעֲבָדִים״ נָפְקָא.
human_translation: The Sages taught “If he comes in begappo he shall leave begappo ” he enters with his body [ begufo ] he shall leave with his body [ begufo ]. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: he enters alone he shall leave alone. What he enters with his body he shall leave with his body? Rava said: to say that he is not released through extremities like slave Abaye said to This is derived “She shall not go out as the men slaves do”
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "If it enters with its body, it must exit with its body" - when it enters with its body, it must exit with its body. Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: If an individual enters, an individual must exit. What does it mean that it enters with its body and exits with its body? Rava said: To say that it does not exit through the openings of the limbs like a servant. Abaye said to him: That - it is derived from "they shall not go out as the male slaves go out."

hebrew_text: אִי מֵהָתָם, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: נִיתֵּיב לֵיהּ דְּמֵי עֵינֵיהּ וְנִיפּוֹק, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: If were from there, I would say: should give him the value of the eye and let him be released. teaches us
llm_translation: From there, I would say: he set aside the value of her eyes and left, which implies to us.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: יְחִידִי נִכְנַס יְחִידִי יֵצֵא. מַאי יְחִידִי יֵצֵא? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק הָכִי קָאָמַר: יֵשׁ לוֹ אִשָּׁה וּבָנִים – רַבּוֹ מוֹסֵר לוֹ שִׁפְחָה כְּנַעֲנִית, אֵין לוֹ אִשָּׁה וּבָנִים – אֵין רַבּוֹ מוֹסֵר לוֹ שִׁפְחָה כְּנַעֲנִית.
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: he enters alone, he shall leave alone. What He shall leave alone? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said this is what is saying: has a wife and children his master may provide him a Canaanite maidservant. he did not have a wife and children, his master may not provide him a Canaanite maidservant.
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: "A bachelor enters, a bachelor leaves." What is meant by "a bachelor leaves"? Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said thus: If he has a wife and children, his master provides him with a Canaanite maidservant. If he does not have a wife and children, his master does not provide him with a Canaanite maidservant.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: נִמְכַּר בְּמָנֶה, וְהִשְׁבִּיחַ וְעָמַד עַל מָאתַיִם, מִנַּיִן שֶׁאֵין מְחַשְּׁבִין לוֹ, אֶלָּא מָנֶה – שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״מִכֶּסֶף מִקְנָתוֹ״.
human_translation: The Sages taught: was sold for one hundred dinars and increased and stood at two hundred from where that one assesses him, only one hundred dinars, As it is stated: “Out of the money that he was bought for”
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: If one was sold for a hundred, and he increased and stood at two hundred, from where do we derive that we do not calculate for him, except for a hundred? As it is stated: "From the money of his purchase."

hebrew_text: נִמְכַּר בְּמָאתַיִם וְהִכְסִיף וְעָמַד עַל מָנֶה, מִנַּיִן שֶׁאֵין מְחַשְּׁבִין לוֹ אֶלָּא מָנֶה – תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כְּפִי שָׁנָיו״.
human_translation: he was sold for two hundred and decreased and stood at one hundred dinars, from where that one assesses him only one hundred dinars? The verse states: “According to his years
llm_translation: He was sold for two hundred and he added and stood on a maneh, from where do we derive that we only calculate for him a maneh - the Talmud says: "according to his years."

hebrew_text: אֵין לִי אֶלָּא עֶבֶד הַנִּמְכָּר לְנׇכְרִי, הוֹאִיל וְנִגְאָל בִּקְרוֹבִים – יָדוֹ עַל הַתַּחְתּוֹנָה.
human_translation: I have only a slave sold to a gentile, since he may be redeemed by relatives is at a disadvantage,
llm_translation: I have nothing except a slave sold to a non-Jew, since he was redeemed by relatives - his hand is on the lower part.

hebrew_text: נִמְכָּר לְיִשְׂרָאֵל מְנָלַן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״שָׂכִיר״ ״שָׂכִיר״ לִגְזֵירָה שָׁוָה.
human_translation: sold to a Jew, from where do we The verse states a hired worker a hired worker for a verbal analogy.
llm_translation: Sold to an Israelite from where? The Talmud says: "Hired" "Hired" is equivalent to a decree.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הֲרֵינִי כְּבֶן עַזַּאי בְּשׁוּקֵי טְבֶרְיָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ הָהוּא מֵרַבָּנַן לְאַבָּיֵי: מִכְּדִי הָנֵי קְרָאֵי אִיכָּא לְמִידְרְשִׁינְהוּ לְקוּלָּא וְאִיכָּא לְמִידְרְשִׁינְהוּ לְחוּמְרָא. מַאי חָזֵית (דְּדַרְשִׁינְהוּ) [לְמִידְרְשִׁינְהוּ] לְקוּלָּא? נִידְרְשִׁינְהוּ לְחוּמְרָא!
human_translation: Abaye said: Behold I am like ben Azzai, in the markets of Tiberias. One of the Sages said to Abaye: After all, those verses: one could expound them leniently, And one could, expound them stringently, What did you see to expound them leniently? Let us expound them stringently.
llm_translation: Abaye said: "Behold, I am like Ben Azai in the markets of Tiberias." That certain Sage said to Abaye: "Since these verses can be expounded for leniency and these verses can be expounded for stringency, what do you see (that you expound them) for leniency? They should be expounded for stringency!"

hebrew_text: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, מִדְּאַקֵּיל רַחֲמָנָא לְגַבֵּיהּ. דְּתַנְיָא: ״כִּי טוֹב לוֹ עִמָּךְ״ – עִמְּךָ בַּמַּאֲכָל וְעִמְּךָ בַּמִּשְׁתֶּה,
human_translation: It cannot enter your mind from that the Merciful One is lenient with regard to As it is taught “Because he fares well with you” with you, in food, with you in drink.
llm_translation: Your understanding is not correct, as the Merciful One is lenient towards him. As it was taught: "For it is good for him with you" - with you in eating and with you in drinking.

hebrew_text: שֶׁלֹּא תְּהֵא אַתָּה אוֹכֵל פַּת נְקִיָּה וְהוּא אוֹכֵל פַּת קִיבָּר, אַתָּה שׁוֹתֶה יַיִן יָשָׁן וְהוּא שׁוֹתֶה יַיִן חָדָשׁ, אַתָּה יָשֵׁן עַל גַּבֵּי מוֹכִים וְהוּא יָשֵׁן עַל גַּבֵּי הַתֶּבֶן. מִכָּאן אָמְרוּ: כׇּל הַקּוֹנֶה עֶבֶד עִבְרִי כְּקוֹנֶה אָדוֹן לְעַצְמוֹ.
human_translation: that there shall not which you eat fine bread and he eats inferior bread [ kibbar ], you drink aged wine and he drinks new wine. you sleep on soft sheets and he sleeps on straw. From here stated: Anyone who acquires a Hebrew slave like one who acquires a master for himself,
llm_translation: One should not eat clean bread while the other eats spoiled bread, one should drink old wine while the other drinks new wine, one should sleep on a bed of ropes while the other sleeps on a bed of straw. From here they said: Whoever acquires a Hebrew slave is as if he has acquired a master for himself.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא: הָנֵי מִילֵּי לְעִנְיַן אֲכִילָה וּשְׁתִיָּה, כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא לִיצְטַעַר לֵיהּ, הָא לְעִנְיַן פִּדְיוֹן נַחְמִיר עֲלֵיהּ. מִדְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא. דְּתַנְיָא: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא אוֹמֵר: בֹּא וּרְאֵה כַּמָּה קָשֶׁה אֲבָקָהּ שֶׁל שְׁבִיעִית:
human_translation: But say this applies to the matter of eating and drinking, so not to cause him suffering. to the matter of redemption, one should be stringent with him. based on of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina. As it is taught Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: Come and see how harsh is a hint of the Sabbatical
llm_translation: And why? These matters regarding eating and drinking, so that he will not suffer, but regarding redemption, we are stringent with it. From Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina. As it was taught: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina says: Come and see how difficult is the dust of the Sabbatical year.

hebrew_text: אָדָם נוֹשֵׂא וְנוֹתֵן בְּפֵירוֹת שְׁבִיעִית – לְסוֹף מוֹכֵר אֶת מִטַּלְטְלָיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בִּשְׁנַת הַיּוֹבֵל תָּשֻׁבוּ אִישׁ אֶל אֲחֻזָּתוֹ״, וּסְמִיךְ לֵיהּ: ״וְכִי תִמְכְּרוּ מִמְכָּר לַעֲמִיתֶךָ אוֹ קָנֹה מִיַּד עֲמִיתֶךָ״ – דָּבָר הַנִּקְנֶה מִיָּד לְיָד.
human_translation: a person has commercial dealings with Sabbatical- produce, ultimately he will sell his movable property, as it is stated: “In Jubilee Year you shall return every man to his land” and juxtaposed to it “And if you sell any item to your neighbor or buy from your neighbor’s hand” an item acquired from hand to hand.
llm_translation: A person carries and gives in the fruits of the seventh year - at the end of the sale he moves his movable property, as it is stated: "In the year of the Jubilee each man shall return to his possession," and adjacent to it: "And if you sell anything to your neighbor or acquire anything from the hand of your neighbor" - a matter that is acquired from hand to hand.

hebrew_text: לֹא הִרְגִּישׁ – לְסוֹף מוֹכֵר אֶת שְׂדוֹתָיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי יָמוּךְ אָחִיךָ וּמָכַר מֵאֲחֻזָּתוֹ״. לֹא בָּאת לְיָדוֹ עַד שֶׁמּוֹכֵר אֶת בֵּיתוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי יִמְכֹּר בֵּית מוֹשַׁב עִיר חוֹמָה״.
human_translation: does not sense ultimately he sell his fields, as it is stated “If your brother grows poor and sells of his ancestral land” no comes to his hand, he will sell his house, as it is stated: sells a dwelling-house in a walled city”
llm_translation: He did not feel - at the end he sells his fields, as it is stated: "When your brother becomes impoverished and sells some of his property." It does not come into his possession until he sells his house, as it is stated: "When he sells a residential house in a walled city."

hebrew_text: מַאי שְׁנָא הָתָם דְּאָמַר ״לֹא הִרְגִּישׁ״ וּמַאי שְׁנָא הָכָא דְּאָמַר ״לֹא בָּאת לְיָדוֹ״? כִּדְרַב הוּנָא, דְּאָמַר רַב הוּנָא: כֵּיוָן שֶׁעָבַר אָדָם עֲבֵירָה וְשָׁנָה בָּהּ – הוּתְּרָה לוֹ. הוּתְּרָה לוֹ סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ? אֶלָּא, נַעֲשֵׂית לוֹ כְּהֶיתֵּר.
human_translation: What is different there, in says: He does not sense, and what is different here, in says: no comes to his hand? in accordance with of Rav Huna. As Rav Huna says: Once a person commits a transgression and repeats it, it is permitted to him. Can it enter your mind that it is permitted to him Rather, it becomes to him as though permitted.
llm_translation: What is the difference there that it says "he did not realize," and what is the difference here that it says "it did not come into his hand"? Like Rav Huna said, as Rav Huna said: Once a person commits a transgression and repeats it, it becomes permitted to him. Becomes permitted to him? Is it really your opinion? Rather, it becomes to him as if it is permitted.

hebrew_text: לֹא בָּאת לְיָדוֹ עַד שֶׁמּוֹכֵר אֶת בִּתּוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְכִי יִמְכֹּר אִישׁ אֶת בִּתּוֹ לְאָמָה״, וְאַף עַל גַּב דְּבִתּוֹ לָא כְּתִיבָא בְּהַאי עִנְיָנָא, הָא קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן: נִיזַבֵּין אִינָשׁ בְּרַתֵּיה וְלָא נֵיזִיף בְּרִיבִּיתָא. מַאי טַעְמָא – בְּרַתֵּיה מְגָרְעָא וְנָפְקָא וְהָא מוֹסְפָא וְאָזְלָא.
human_translation: no comes to his hand, until he sells his daughter, as it is stated: “And when a man sells his daughter as a maidservant” And even though “his daughter” is not written with regard to that matter it teaches us this A person will sell his daughter rather than borrow with interest What is the reason His daughter can deduct and leave but this continuously increases.
llm_translation: He did not come into his possession until he sells his daughter, as it is stated: "And if a man sells his daughter to be a maidservant." And even though with regard to his daughter it is not explicitly written in this context, it teaches us: People are preoccupied with their daughters and do not engage in usury. What is the reason? - His daughter is subtracted and goes out, while the interest is added and goes away.

hebrew_text: לֹא בָּאת לְיָדוֹ עַד שֶׁלֹּוֶה בְּרִבִּית, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְכִי יָמוּךְ אָחִיךָ וּמָטָה יָדוֹ עִמָּךְ״, וּסְמִיךְ לֵיהּ: ״אַל תִּקַּח מֵאִתּוֹ וְגוֹ׳״. לֹא בָּאת לְיָדוֹ עַד שֶׁמּוֹכֵר אֶת עַצְמוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְכִי יָמוּךְ אָחִיךָ וְנִמְכַּר לָךְ״.
human_translation: no comes to his hand, he borrow with interest, as it is stated: “And if your brother grows poor and his means fails with you” and juxtaposed to it “Take no from him” no comes to his hand, he will sell himself, as it is stated: “And if your brother grows poor and sells himself to you”
llm_translation: He did not come into his possession until he borrows with interest, as it is stated: "And if your brother becomes poor and his hand falters with you," and juxtaposed to it: "Do not take from him." He did not come into his possession until he sells himself, as it is stated: "And if your brother becomes poor and is sold to you."

hebrew_text: לֹא לְךָ אֶלָּא לְגֵר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לְגֵר״, וְלֹא לְגֵר צֶדֶק אֶלָּא לְגֵר תּוֹשָׁב שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״גֵּר תּוֹשָׁב״. ״מִשְׁפַּחַת גֵּר״ – זֶה נׇכְרִי. כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר: ״לְעֵקֶר״
human_translation: Not to you, but to a stranger, as it is stated: to a stranger [ ger ]” And not to a righteous convert [ ger tzedek ], but to a gentile who resides in Eretz Yisrael and observes the seven Noahide mitzvot [ ger toshav ], as it is stated: a stranger who is a settler [ ger toshav ]” “A stranger’s family”; this is a gentile, When it says: “To an offshoot
llm_translation: Not for you, but for the convert, as it is stated: "for the convert," and not for the righteous convert, but for the resident convert, as it is stated: "resident convert." "The family of the convert" – this refers to a non-Jew. When he says: "to uproot."

hebrew_text: – זֶה הַנִּמְכָּר לַעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה עַצְמָהּ.
human_translation: this is one sold for idol worship itself,
llm_translation: This is the one sold for foreign service itself.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָתָם, הָא אַהְדְּרֵיהּ קְרָא, דְּתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: הוֹאִיל וְהָלַךְ זֶה וְנַעֲשָׂה כּוֹמֶר לַעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה, אֵימָא: לִידְחֵי אֶבֶן אַחַר הַנּוֹפֵל – תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אַחֲרֵי נִמְכַּר גְּאֻלָּה תִּהְיֶה לּוֹ אֶחָד מֵאֶחָיו יִגְאָלֶנּוּ״.
human_translation: said to There, the verse brings him back, As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Since this has gone and become a priest for idol worship, say: Let us throw a stone after the fallen, the verse states: “After he is sold he shall be redeemed; one of his brothers may redeem him”
llm_translation: He said to him: There, this, the verse repeats, as the school of Rabbi Ishmael teaches: Since this one went and became a priest for idol worship, say: Let another stone fall after him - the Scripture states: "After it is sold, there shall be redemption for him; one of his brothers shall redeem him."

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא: ״גְּאוּלָּה תִּהְיֶה לוֹ״ – כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא לִיטַּמַּע בֵּין הַנׇּכְרִים, הָא לְעִנְיַן פִּדְיוֹן נַחְמִיר עֲלֵיהּ, מִדְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא!
human_translation: But say “He shall be redeemed,” he will not be assimilated among the gentiles. with regard to the matter of redemption let us act strictly with him, from that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,
llm_translation: And why? "Redemption shall be for him" - so that he does not become mingled among the nations, but regarding the matter of redemption, Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Chanina is stringent about it!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: תְּרֵי קְרָאֵי כְּתִיבִי. כְּתִיב: ״אִם עוֹד רַבּוֹת בַּשָּׁנִים״ וּכְתִיב: ״וְאִם מְעַט נִשְׁאַר בַּשָּׁנִים״. וְכִי יֵשׁ שָׁנִים מְרוּבּוֹת וְיֵשׁ שָׁנִים מוּעָטוֹת? אֶלָּא, נִתְרַבָּה כַּסְפּוֹ – ״מִכֶּסֶף מִקְנָתוֹ״, נִתְמַעֵט כַּסְפּוֹ – ״כְּפִי שָׁנָיו״.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Two verses are written It is written: “If there be yet many of the years, and it is written: “And if there remain but few of the years But there be many years and few years Rather, money his increased “out of the money that he was bought for,” his monetary decreased “according to his years,”
llm_translation: Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: Two verses are written. It is written: "If his wealth has increased in the years," and it is written: "But if his wealth has decreased in the years." Are there years that are mostly abundant and years that are mostly scarce? Rather, when his wealth increases - "from the money of his acquisition," when his wealth decreases - "according to his years."

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא הָכִי קָאָמַר: הֵיכָא דַּעֲבַד תְּרֵי וּפֻשׁ לֵיהּ אַרְבַּע – נִיתֵּיב לֵיהּ אַרְבַּע ״מִכֶּסֶף מִקְנָתוֹ״, עֲבַד אַרְבַּע וּפֻשׁו לֵיהּ תַּרְתֵּי – נִיתֵּיב תַּרְתֵּי ״כְּפִי שָׁנָיו״?
human_translation: But say this is what is saying: where he served two and four years remain for his let him give four “out of the money that he was bought for.” he served four and two years remain for his let him give two “according to his years.”
